Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans.

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when w

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these st

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize h

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jo

 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to their

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bill

I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bills. 
We need more portrayals of college aged characters that are book nerds, gay, Asian, Latino, disabled or otherwise diverse.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bills. 
We need more portrayals of college aged characters that are book nerds, gay, Asian, Latino, disabled or otherwise diverse.
 We need to show how hard it is to get a wheelchair aro

I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bills. 
We need more portrayals of college aged characters that are book nerds, gay, Asian, Latino, disabled or otherwise diverse.
 We need to show how hard it is to get a wheelchair around an old Ivy Lea

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bills. 
We need more portrayals of college aged characters that are book nerds, gay, Asian, Latino, disabled or otherwise diverse.
 We need to show how hard it is to get a wheelchair around an old Ivy League campus that has their di

I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bills. 
We need more portrayals of college aged characters that are book nerds, gay, Asian, Latino, disabled or otherwise diverse.
 We need to show how hard it is to get a wheelchair around an old Ivy League campus that has their disabled students in a bui

I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bills. 
We need more portrayals of college aged characters that are book nerds, gay, Asian, Latino, disabled or otherwise diverse.

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bills. 
We need more portrayals of college aged characters that are book nerds, gay, Asian, Latino, disabled or otherwise diverse.
 We need to show how hard it is to get a wheelchair around an old Ivy League campus that has their disabled students in a building seperate all of the other dorms because the reg

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bills.

 We need to show how hard it is to get a wheelchair around an old Ivy League campus that has their disabled students in a building seperate all of the other dorms because the regular dorms aren't able to be lived in by them

In my opinion, there is an obnoxious stereotype surrounding college fraternity and sororities. So many books, tv shows and movies make it seem like every college student in the US is a "dude-bro" frat boy or giggly sorority sister who drinks and parties every single night.
Many of these same films or tv shows have other major flaws, but the over-the-top fictional frat/sorority aspect
 is detrimental to the already bad views people have of Americans. 
I think it's the same reason I cringe at shows like Friday Night Lights or GCW television shows. Everyone is gorgeous and a size zero or a hard muscled jock that can eat pizza and drink beer for 4 years straight and never gain a pound. This is not a realistic view of college life.

As an adult who graduated 20 years ago, the stereotypes still bother me because you now have people arguing that "we all do dumb things when we're 18" because they see these stereotypes playing out in books and movies. Little do they realize how many of those college aged students are working 2 part time jobs, being a TA and having to send money back home to help their family pay bills. 
We need more portrayals of college aged characters that are book nerds, gay, Asian, Latino, disabled or otherwise diverse.
 We need to show how hard it is to get a wheelchair around an old Ivy League campus that has their disabled students in a building separate all of the other dorms because the regular dorms aren't able to be lived in by them.

Don't feed the sterei
